docs.title: SuperviseMe
docs.text: Welcome to SuperviseMe, a comprehensive platform designed to streamline thesis supervision and research project management within academic institutions. By providing dedicated environments for administrators, supervisors, researchers, and students, SuperviseMe fosters collaboration and simplifies the complexities of academic research management.

docs.title: Start Here
docs.text:
If you are new to the project, begin with:

  1. Installation and First Run
  2. Configuration

docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text: In the dynamic world of academia, managing thesis supervision and research projects can be a daunting task. SuperviseMe addresses this challenge by offering a centralized, Flask-based web application that caters to the distinct needs of all stakeholders. Whether you are an administrator overseeing the entire system, a supervisor guiding students, a researcher collaborating on projects, or a student working on your thesis, SuperviseMe provides the tools you need to succeed.

docs.title: Secure and Flexible Authentication
docs.text: Security is paramount in SuperviseMe. We employ a robust email-based authentication system secured with PBKDF2-SHA256 password hashing. Recognizing the diversity of user preferences, we also support seamless social login integration with Google and ORCID, ensuring that access to your dashboard is both secure and convenient. Our role-based access control system ensures that every user—from administrators to students—sees exactly what they need to see, with appropriate permissions for their specific responsibilities.

docs.title: Empowering Administrators
docs.text: Administrators are the backbone of the SuperviseMe ecosystem. The platform equips them with a powerful dashboard to manage users, monitor system health, and oversee the distribution of theses. With tools for detailed activity monitoring, email notification configuration, and system-wide data export, administrators maintain full control over the platform's operation.

docs.title: Supporting Supervisors
docs.text: SuperviseMe transforms the supervision experience. Supervisors can easily track student progress, provide timely feedback, and share essential resources. The automated weekly email reports ensure that supervisors start their week with a clear summary of their students' activities, while visual indicators help identify students who may need extra support or engagement.

docs.title: Facilitating Research
docs.text: For researchers, SuperviseMe offers a collaborative workspace to manage projects and teams. Researchers can create projects, invite collaborators, and track milestones with ease. The platform supports dual roles, allowing researchers to also act as supervisors when needed, bridging the gap between personal research and academic mentorship.

docs.title: Guiding Students
docs.text: Students benefit from a clear, organized dashboard that keeps their thesis journey on track. From viewing thesis requirements to submitting progress updates and accessing supervisor-provided materials, students have a central hub for all their academic responsibilities.

docs.title: Notification System
docs.text:
Communication is key to successful supervision. SuperviseMe integrates a multi-channel notification system to keep everyone in the loop.

Telegram Integration: For urgent updates and real-time alerts, users can connect their Telegram accounts to receive instant notifications directly to their devices.

Weekly Insights: Our automated email system delivers professional, structured reports every Monday morning, providing supervisors with a digest of student activities and highlighting any areas that require attention.

docs.title: Technical Architecture
docs.text: Built on a solid foundation of modern technologies, SuperviseMe leverages the power of Flask for a flexible backend, SQLAlchemy for robust database management, and Bootstrap for a responsive, user-friendly frontend. The system is designed for reliability and scalability, utilizing Celery or APScheduler for background tasks and supporting both SQLite and PostgreSQL databases to suit different deployment needs.

docs.title: Configuration and Settings
docs.text: SuperviseMe is configured using environment variables. These can be set in a .env file in the root directory or as system environment variables.

docs.title: General Configuration

Must be strong and unique in production. change-this... Yes (in prod) DEBUG Enable Flask debug mode. docs.title: SuperviseMe Database Setup
docs.text: This document describes how to set up and recreate the SuperviseMe database from scratch.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The SuperviseMe application uses a comprehensive database schema with 28 tables to manage users, theses, research projects, tasks, notifications, and more. The database supports both SQLite (for development) and PostgreSQL (for production).

docs.title: Database Tables
docs.text: The complete database schema includes:

docs.title: Core Tables
docs.text:
• user_mgmt - User management and authentication
  • thesis - Thesis projects
  • thesis_status - Thesis status tracking
  • thesis_supervisor - Thesis-supervisor relationships
  • thesis_tag - Thesis tagging system
  • thesis_update - Thesis progress updates
  • thesis_objective - Thesis objectives
  • thesis_hypothesis - Thesis hypotheses

docs.title: Task Management
docs.text:
• todo - Task management
  • todo_reference - Links between tasks and updates
  • update_tag - Tags for updates

docs.title: Communication & Resources
docs.text:
• notification - User notifications
  • meeting_note - Meeting notes
  • meeting_note_reference - Links between meeting notes and tasks
  • resource - File and link resources
  • telegram_bot_config - Telegram integration settings

docs.title: Research Projects
docs.text:
• research_project - Research project management
  • research_project_collaborator - Project collaborators
  • research_project_status - Project status tracking
  • research_project_update - Project updates
  • research_project_resource - Project resources
  • research_project_objective - Project objectives
  • research_project_hypothesis - Project hypotheses
  • research_project_todo - Project tasks
  • research_project_meeting_note - Project meeting notes
  • research_project_todo_reference - Project task references
  • research_project_meeting_note_reference - Project meeting note references

docs.title: Administration
docs.text: • supervisor_role - Supervisor role management

docs.title: Automatic Recreation (Recommended)
docs.text:
Use the provided database recreation script to completely rebuild the database:

# Recreate SQLite database (development)
python recreate_database.py --db-type sqlite --force --test

# Recreate PostgreSQL database (production) - requires PostgreSQL service
python recreate_database.py --db-type postgresql --force --test

docs.title: Script Options
docs.text:
• --db-type: Choose between sqlite or postgresql
  • --force: Skip confirmation prompts
  • --test: Run functionality tests after recreation

docs.title: What the Script Does
docs.text:
1. Backup: Creates a timestamped backup of existing database
  2. Drop/Create: Removes old database and creates new one
  3. Schema: Creates all 28 tables according to models.py
  4. Admin User: Creates default admin user (username: admin, password: test)
  5. Verification: Confirms all expected tables were created
  6. Testing: Optional functionality tests

docs.title: Manual Database Management
docs.text:
If you need to manually manage the database:

from superviseme import create_app, db

# Create app with database initialization disabled
app = create_app(db_type="sqlite", skip_user_init=True)

with app.app_context():
    # Create all tables
    db.create_all()

    # Create admin user
    from superviseme.models import User_mgmt
    from werkzeug.security import generate_password_hash
    import time

    admin_user = User_mgmt(
        username="admin",
        name="System",
        surname="Administrator",
        email="admin@superviseme.local",
        password=generate_password_hash("test"),
        user_type="admin",
        joined_on=int(time.time())
    )
    db.session.add(admin_user)
    db.session.commit()

docs.title: Starting the Application
docs.text:
After database recreation, start the application:

# SQLite (development)
python superviseme.py --db sqlite --port 8080

# PostgreSQL (production)
python superviseme.py --db postgresql --port 8080

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Test the application functionality:

python test_app_functionality.py

This will verify: - Database connectivity and queries - Basic web endpoints - Admin user creation - Application startup

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
1. "no such table: user_mgmt" - Run the database recreation script
  2. Port already in use - Use a different port with --port option
  3. PostgreSQL connection errors - Ensure PostgreSQL service is running
  4. Permission errors - Check file permissions in superviseme/db/ directory

docs.title: Database Location
docs.text:
• SQLite database: superviseme/db/dashboard.db
  • Backups: superviseme/db/dashboard.db.backup_YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
For PostgreSQL, set these environment variables:

export PG_USER="postgres"
export PG_PASSWORD="your_password"
export PG_HOST="localhost"
export PG_PORT="5432"
export PG_DBNAME="superviseme"

docs.title: Default Credentials
docs.text:
After database recreation, you can log in with: - Username: admin - Email: admin@superviseme.local - Password: test

⚠️ Important: Change the default admin password after first login in production!

docs.title: Migration from Old Database
docs.text:
If you have an existing database with partial tables, the recreation script will: 1. Create a backup of your existing database 2. Create a completely new database with all required tables 3. You can manually migrate important data from the backup if needed

The script does not attempt to migrate existing data - it creates a fresh database. If you need to preserve existing data, consider creating a custom migration script based on your specific needs.

docs.title: SuperviseMe Deployment Readiness Report (Updated)
docs.text: Date: 2026-02-19 Scope: repository-wide technical readiness for production deployment

docs.title: 1. Executive Summary
docs.text:
Readiness has improved substantially. Core route integrity and destructive action safety are now in better shape, CSRF protection is active, scheduler role isolation is configurable, CI gates are in place, and schema alignment checks are automated.

Current recommendation: not fully production-ready yet due to unresolved PostgreSQL initialization defects and limited automated coverage of business-critical workflows.

docs.title: Completed / improved
docs.text:
1. Route correctness and CRUD reliability
  2. Previously broken endpoint references in templates were fixed.
  3. Destructive/toggle operations that were GET-based are now non-GET.
  4. Static audit confirms:
  5. destructive GET routes: 0

  6. unresolved url_for(...) references: 0

  7. Thesis deletion reliability

  8. Shared deletion utility now removes dependent records consistently.

  9. Wired into admin/supervisor/researcher deletion flows.

  10. Security hardening

  11. App-wide CSRF protection added and enforced.
  12. Shared templates now include CSRF token and auto-attach token for mutating forms/fetch requests.
  13. Verified behavior:

  14. POST without CSRF token is rejected.

  15. Scheduler isolation control

  16. Scheduler can be disabled per process using ENABLE_SCHEDULER.

  17. Supports “single scheduler worker” deployment pattern.

  18. Delivery quality gates

  19. CI workflow added (.github/workflows/ci.yml) with:
  20. runtime-safety lint
  21. compile checks
  22. schema/model alignment check
  23. test run
  24. Added scripts/check_schema_alignment.py.

  25. Added local shortcuts via Makefile (make ci, make smoke).

  26. Operational documentation

  27. Added DEPLOYMENT_RUNBOOK.md with preflight, rollout, smoke, rollback, backup/restore.
  28. Updated README and Docker docs for scheduler/seeding behavior and seed password controls.

docs.title: High Severity
docs.text:
1. PostgreSQL initialization path is internally inconsistent and likely broken
  2. File: superviseme/__init__.py:46
  3. Issues:
  4. Uses string replacement on URI (replace("dashboard", "postgres")) instead of robust parsing.
  5. “Dummy DB” branch checks datname = dbname again rather than a distinct DB name.
  6. References app.config["SQLALCHEMY_BINDS"]["db_exp"] although db_exp is not configured.
  7. Loads postgre_server.sql in a path that appears disconnected from active runtime use.

  8. Risk: first-time PostgreSQL provisioning may fail or behave unpredictably.

  9. No formal migration framework

  10. Database changes are managed via ad-hoc scripts.
  11. Risk: schema drift and non-repeatable upgrades across environments.

docs.title: Medium Severity
docs.text:
1. Automated tests are still too shallow for release confidence
  2. Current suite passes, but only two tests are present.

  3. Missing regression coverage for role-critical CRUD + authorization flows.

  4. Docker seeding remains script-driven and easy to misuse

  5. Improvement: compose default now sets SKIP_DB_SEED=true.

  6. Remaining risk: manual env drift could re-enable seeding unexpectedly in production.

  7. Legacy/unreferenced template backup files in tree

  8. Example: superviseme/templates/researcher/supervisor_thesis_detail_old.html
  9. Risk: maintenance confusion and accidental usage.

docs.title: 4. Quality Gate Status (Current)
docs.text:
• Lint (ruff runtime-safety set): pass
  • Compile checks: pass
  • Schema alignment check: pass
  • Tests (pytest -q): pass (2 passed)

docs.title: Phase 5 (Immediate correctness, 1-3 days)
docs.text:
1. Replace create_postgresql_db with a single, deterministic PostgreSQL bootstrap path.
  2. Remove dead db_exp / dummy-db logic and unused SQL bootstrap branches.
  3. Add explicit integration test for PostgreSQL startup path.

docs.title: Phase 6 (Schema governance, 3-5 days)
docs.text:
1. Introduce Alembic migrations.
  2. Baseline current schema and convert migration scripts into ordered revisions.
  3. Enforce migration check in CI (upgrade on ephemeral DB).

docs.title: Phase 7 (Reliability testing, 4-7 days)
docs.text:
1. Add end-to-end role workflow tests:
  2. admin user/thesis CRUD
  3. supervisor thesis lifecycle + todo/update operations
  4. researcher dual-role flows
  5. student thesis update/resource/todo operations
  6. Add authorization negative tests (cross-role and cross-ownership attempts).

docs.title: Phase 8 (Release hardening, 3-5 days)
docs.text:
1. Add staging smoke automation script aligned with DEPLOYMENT_RUNBOOK.md.
  2. Add backup/restore rehearsal procedure and evidence template.
  3. Remove legacy template backups and stale artifacts.

docs.title: 6. Deployability Definition (Revised)
docs.text:
Production deployment sign-off should require:

  1. PostgreSQL bootstrap path fixed and tested.
  2. Alembic migration workflow operational in CI/CD.
  3. Expanded automated workflow coverage for all core roles.
  4. Scheduler single-worker topology validated in staging.
  5. Runbook smoke + rollback rehearsal completed.

docs.title: Deployment Runbook
docs.text: This document outlines the procedures for deploying, maintaining, and recovering the SuperviseMe application in a production environment.

docs.title: 1. Pre-Deployment Checklist
docs.text:
Before deploying any changes or updates:

  • [ ] Code Review: Ensure all code changes have been reviewed and approved.
  • [ ] Testing: Run all automated tests (make test) and ensure they pass.
  • [ ] Schema Alignment: Check for database schema changes (make schema).
  • [ ] Environment Variables: Verify that all necessary environment variables are set in the .env file (or deployment secrets).
  • [ ] Backup: Create a backup of the current database.

docs.title: 2.1. Initial Deployment
docs.text:
1. Clone Repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/GiulioRossetti/SuperviseMe.git
cd SuperviseMe

  2. Configure Environment:

    • Copy .env.example to .env.
    • Update values for SECRET_KEY, ADMIN_BOOTSTRAP_PASSWORD, PG_PASSWORD, etc.
    • Important: Set FLASK_ENV=production.

  3. Setup SSL:

    • Generate or place SSL certificates in nginx/ssl/.

  4. Start Services: 

    docker-compose up -d

  5. Initialize Database (if needed):

    • The application will automatically create tables if they don't exist.
    • Wait for the services to be healthy (docker-compose ps).

docs.title: 2.2. Updating the Application
docs.text:
1. Pull Latest Changes: 

    git pull origin main

  2. Rebuild Containers: 

    docker-compose build

  3. Apply Updates: 

    docker-compose up -d

    • Docker Compose will recreate containers with configuration or image changes.

  4. Run Migrations:

    • If there are database schema changes, run the migration scripts: 
      docker-compose exec superviseme_app python migrate_database.py
docker-compose exec superviseme_app python migrate_telegram.py
docker-compose exec superviseme_app python migrate_researcher.py

docs.title: 3.1. Database Backups
docs.text:
• Manual Backup: 
    docker-compose exec postgres pg_dump -U superviseme_user superviseme > backup_$(date +%Y%m%d).sql
  • Automated Backup: Schedule a cron job on the host machine to run the backup command daily.

docs.title: 3.2. Log Monitoring
docs.text:
• View logs for all services: 
    docker-compose logs -f
  • View logs for a specific service: 
    docker-compose logs -f superviseme_app

docs.title: 4.1. Restore Database
docs.text:
1. Stop Application: 

    docker-compose stop superviseme_app

  2. Restore from Backup: 

    cat backup.sql | docker-compose exec -T postgres psql -U superviseme_user -d superviseme

  3. Restart Application: 

    docker-compose start superviseme_app

docs.title: 5. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Service Unhealthy: Check logs (docker-compose logs) for error messages.
  • Database Connection Error: Verify PG_HOST, PG_USER, and PG_PASSWORD in .env.
  • Nginx 502 Bad Gateway: The Flask application might be down or starting up. Check superviseme_app logs.
  • Email Issues: Check mailhog UI or SMTP server logs. Verify MAIL_SERVER settings.

docs.title: 6. Smoke Tests
docs.text:
After deployment, perform a smoke test to verify basic functionality:

  1. Access the homepage (https://your-domain.com).
  2. Log in as an administrator.
  3. Check the "System Status" or dashboard for any alerts.
  4. Send a test email from the Admin Dashboard.

docs.title: SuperviseMe Deployment Runbook
docs.text: This runbook defines a repeatable deployment process for production.

docs.title: 1. Preconditions
docs.text:
• CI must pass on the target commit:
  • lint (ruff runtime-safety rules)
  • compile checks
  • schema alignment check
  • tests (pytest)
  • Target environment must provide required secrets:
  • SECRET_KEY (strong, non-default)
  • ADMIN_BOOTSTRAP_PASSWORD
  • database credentials
  • mail/telegram credentials if used
  • Exactly one process/service must run scheduler jobs:
  • ENABLE_SCHEDULER=true only for scheduler worker
  • set ENABLE_SCHEDULER=false for web app replicas

docs.title: 2. Pre-Deployment Checklist
docs.text:
1. Confirm current production health endpoint:
  2. GET /health returns 200.
  3. Confirm backup availability and last successful backup timestamp.
  4. Confirm rollback artifact exists (previous container image/tag).
  5. Confirm .env values are present and valid in deployment target.
  6. Confirm database schema file alignment in repo:
  7. python scripts/check_schema_alignment.py --db data_schema/database_dashboard.db --strict

docs.title: 3. Deployment Procedure
docs.text:
1. Pull target release artifacts (or checkout release commit).
  2. Install/update dependencies:
  3. pip install -r requirements.txt
  4. Ensure environment variables are set:
  5. production SECRET_KEY
  6. ENABLE_SCHEDULER set per role (web vs scheduler worker)
  7. Restart services:
  8. web service(s)
  9. scheduler service (single instance only)
  10. Wait for startup logs and confirm no initialization failures.

docs.title: 4. Post-Deploy Smoke Tests
docs.text:
Run immediately after rollout:

  1. Basic availability
  2. GET /health -> 200
  3. GET /login -> 200
  4. Authentication + CSRF
  5. login form renders token
  6. login POST without CSRF -> blocked (400)
  7. login POST with CSRF -> accepted flow
  8. Role access sanity
  9. admin dashboard loads
  10. supervisor thesis list loads
  11. researcher projects/supervisor dashboards load
  12. student thesis page loads
  13. Critical CRUD checks
  14. thesis delete (admin/supervisor/researcher) succeeds with expected permissions
  15. todo toggle/delete works
  16. student objective/resource delete works
  17. Scheduler sanity
  18. only one scheduler instance reports active jobs
  19. no duplicate weekly notification job execution observed

docs.title: 5. Rollback Procedure
docs.text:
Trigger rollback if smoke tests fail or severe errors are detected.

  1. Re-deploy previous known-good image/tag.
  2. Restore previous environment variables if changed.
  3. Restart services and verify:
  4. GET /health returns 200
  5. core login/dashboard routes work
  6. If database changes were applied and are incompatible, restore DB backup.
  7. Document incident:
  8. failed version
  9. symptom
  10. rollback time
  11. follow-up owner

docs.title: Backup
docs.text:
1. Stop write-heavy jobs if possible.
  2. Create database backup (engine-native dump/snapshot).
  3. Store with timestamp and release tag.
  4. Verify backup integrity (test restore metadata at minimum).

docs.title: Restore
docs.text:
1. Put app in maintenance mode.
  2. Restore DB from selected backup.
  3. Re-deploy app version compatible with restored schema/data.
  4. Run smoke tests from section 4 before opening traffic.

docs.title: 7. Operational Notes
docs.text:
• Use ENABLE_SCHEDULER=false in test/CI and in all but one production worker.
  • Keep ADMIN_BOOTSTRAP_PASSWORD for bootstrap only; rotate and store securely.
  • Keep certs/keys out of repo; provide via secret manager/volume at runtime.

docs.title: Docker Deployment Guide
docs.text: This guide describes how to run SuperviseMe using Docker with a complete production-ready setup including reverse proxy, database persistence, and mail server.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
The Docker setup includes the following services:

  • superviseme_app: Flask application running with Gunicorn
  • postgres: PostgreSQL database with persistent storage
  • nginx: Reverse proxy with SSL termination and static file serving
  • mailhog: Development mail server for testing email functionality (use a real SMTP server for production)

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Clone and navigate to the repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/GiulioRossetti/SuperviseMe.git
cd SuperviseMe

  2. Create environment configuration: 

    cp .env.example .env
    Edit .env and customize the values, especially:

  3. SECRET_KEY: Use a strong, unique secret key.
  4. ADMIN_BOOTSTRAP_PASSWORD: Set a strong admin bootstrap password.
  5. PG_PASSWORD: Set a secure database password.
  6. SKIP_DB_SEED: Keep true in production (seed explicitly only when needed).

  7. ENABLE_SCHEDULER: Keep false for web replicas; enable only in one scheduler worker.

  8. Provide TLS files for Nginx:

  9. Place certificate and key files in nginx/ssl/:

    • superviseme.crt
    • superviseme.key

  10. Start the application: 

    docker-compose up -d

  11. Access the application:

  12. Main application: https://localhost (accept the self-signed certificate if running locally)
  13. Mail server UI: http://localhost:8025

docs.title: Web Application (superviseme_app)
docs.text:
• Port: Internal 8080 (proxied through Nginx)
  • Technology: Flask + Gunicorn WSGI server
  • Database: PostgreSQL with automatic schema initialization
  • Health Check: HTTP health endpoint
  • Volumes: Application data persistence

docs.title: Database (postgres)
docs.text:
• Port: Internal 5432
  • Technology: PostgreSQL 15 Alpine
  • Persistence: Named volume postgres_data
  • Initialization: Automatic database and schema creation
  • Health Check: PostgreSQL ready check

docs.title: Reverse Proxy (nginx)
docs.text:
• Ports: 80 (HTTP → HTTPS redirect), 443 (HTTPS)
  • Features:
  • SSL termination
  • Static file serving and caching
  • Rate limiting for security
  • Security headers
  • Gzip compression
  • Health Check: HTTP health endpoint

docs.title: Mail Server (mailhog)
docs.text:
• Ports: 8025 (Web UI), 1025 (SMTP)
  • Purpose: Development mail server for testing notifications.
  • Production: For production, configure an external SMTP server in .env.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Key environment variables (see .env.example):

# Flask Configuration
FLASK_ENV=production
SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key
DEBUG=false
ENABLE_SCHEDULER=false
SKIP_DB_SEED=true

# Database Configuration
PG_USER=superviseme_user
PG_PASSWORD=your-secure-password
PG_DBNAME=superviseme

# Mail Configuration
MAIL_DEFAULT_SENDER=noreply@superviseme.local
MAIL_SERVER=mailhog
MAIL_PORT=1025

docs.title: SSL Certificates
docs.text:
SSL certificates are not auto-generated by the containers. Provide your own certificate and private key in nginx/ssl/.

For local development, you can generate self-signed certificates manually: 

cd nginx/ssl
openssl req -x509 -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 \
  -keyout superviseme.key -out superviseme.crt \
  -subj "/C=US/ST=Dev/L=Local/O=SuperviseMe/CN=localhost"

For production, use a valid certificate from a CA (e.g., Let's Encrypt).

docs.title: Development Mode
docs.text:
For development with hot reloading:

docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.dev.yml up

Development features: - Flask development server with auto-reload - Source code volume mounting - Debug mode enabled - Direct access to application on port 8080

docs.title: Database Data
docs.text:
• Volume: postgres_data
  • Location: PostgreSQL data directory
  • Backup: Use pg_dump through the container: 
    docker-compose exec postgres pg_dump -U superviseme_user superviseme > backup.sql

docs.title: Application Data
docs.text:
• Volume: app_data
  • Location: Application database files and uploads
  • Purpose: Persistent storage for SQLite fallback and file uploads

docs.title: Monitoring and Health Checks
docs.text:
All services include health checks:

docs.title: SuperviseMe Docker Setup
docs.text: This document describes how to run SuperviseMe using Docker with a complete production-ready setup including reverse proxy, database persistence, and mail server.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
The Docker setup includes the following services:

  • superviseme_app: Flask application running with Gunicorn
  • postgres: PostgreSQL database with persistent storage
  • nginx: Reverse proxy with SSL termination and static file serving
  • mailhog: Development mail server for testing email functionality

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Clone and navigate to the repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/GiulioRossetti/SuperviseMe.git
cd SuperviseMe

  2. Create environment configuration: 

    cp .env.example .env
    Edit .env and customize the values, especially:

  3. SECRET_KEY: Use a strong, unique secret key
  4. ADMIN_BOOTSTRAP_PASSWORD: Set a strong admin bootstrap password
  5. PG_PASSWORD: Set a secure database password
  6. SKIP_DB_SEED: Keep true in production (seed explicitly only when needed)

  7. ENABLE_SCHEDULER: Keep false for web replicas; enable only in one scheduler worker

  8. Provide TLS files for Nginx:

  9. Place certificate and key files in nginx/ssl/:

    • superviseme.crt
    • superviseme.key

  10. Start the application: 

    docker-compose up -d

  11. Access the application:

  12. Main application: https://localhost
  13. Mail server UI: http://localhost:8025

docs.title: Web Application (superviseme_app)
docs.text:
• Port: Internal 8080 (proxied through Nginx)
  • Technology: Flask + Gunicorn WSGI server
  • Database: PostgreSQL with automatic schema initialization
  • Health Check: HTTP health endpoint
  • Volumes: Application data persistence

docs.title: Database (postgres)
docs.text:
• Port: Internal 5432
  • Technology: PostgreSQL 15 Alpine
  • Persistence: Named volume postgres_data
  • Initialization: Automatic database and schema creation
  • Health Check: PostgreSQL ready check

docs.title: Reverse Proxy (nginx)
docs.text:
• Ports: 80 (HTTP → HTTPS redirect), 443 (HTTPS)
  • Features:
  • SSL termination
  • Static file serving and caching
  • Rate limiting for security
  • Security headers
  • Gzip compression
  • Health Check: HTTP health endpoint

docs.title: Mail Server (mailhog)
docs.text:
• Ports: 8025 (Web UI), 1025 (SMTP)
  • Purpose: Development mail server for testing notifications
  • Features: Web interface to view sent emails

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Key environment variables (see .env.example):

# Flask Configuration
FLASK_ENV=production
SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key
DEBUG=false
ENABLE_SCHEDULER=false
SKIP_DB_SEED=true

# Database Configuration  
PG_USER=superviseme_user
PG_PASSWORD=your-secure-password
PG_DBNAME=superviseme

# Mail Configuration
MAIL_DEFAULT_SENDER=noreply@superviseme.local
MAIL_SERVER=mailhog
MAIL_PORT=1025

docs.title: SSL Certificates
docs.text:
SSL certificates are not auto-generated by the containers. Provide your own certificate and private key in nginx/ssl/.

For local development, you can generate self-signed certificates manually. For production:

  1. Replace certificates in nginx/ssl/ directory:
  2. superviseme.crt - SSL certificate

  3. superviseme.key - Private key

  4. Update nginx/nginx.conf server_name to match your domain

docs.title: Development Mode
docs.text:
For development with hot reloading:

docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.dev.yml up

Development features: - Flask development server with auto-reload - Source code volume mounting - Debug mode enabled - Direct access to application on port 8080

docs.title: Database Data
docs.text:
• Volume: postgres_data
  • Location: PostgreSQL data directory
  • Backup: Use pg_dump through the container: 
    docker-compose exec postgres pg_dump -U superviseme_user superviseme > backup.sql

docs.title: Application Data
docs.text:
• Volume: app_data
  • Location: Application database files and uploads
  • Purpose: Persistent storage for SQLite fallback and file uploads

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
1. Database Connection Failed: 

    # Check PostgreSQL logs
docker-compose logs postgres

# Verify connection
docker-compose exec postgres pg_isready -U superviseme_user

  2. SSL Certificate Errors: 

    # Regenerate self-signed certificates
cd nginx/ssl
openssl req -x509 -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 \
  -keyout superviseme.key -out superviseme.crt \
  -subj "/C=US/ST=Dev/L=Local/O=SuperviseMe/CN=localhost"

  3. Application Won't Start: 

    # Check application logs
docker-compose logs superviseme_app

# Check database initialization
docker-compose exec superviseme_app python seed_database.py

  4. Nginx Configuration Issues: 

    # Test Nginx configuration
docker-compose exec nginx nginx -t

# Reload Nginx configuration
docker-compose exec nginx nginx -s reload

docs.title: Useful Commands
docs.text:

docker-compose up -d

# Stop services  
docker-compose down

# Rebuild and restart
docker-compose up -d --build

# View real-time logs
docker-compose logs -f

# Execute commands in containers
docker-compose exec superviseme_app bash
docker-compose exec postgres psql -U superviseme_user -d superviseme

# Remove all data (destructive!)
docker-compose down -v

docs.text:
This page covers everything needed before the Configuration page.

docs.title: 1. Prerequisites
docs.text:
Choose one setup path:

  • Local Python setup:
  • Python 3.8+
  • pip
  • (Optional) PostgreSQL if you do not want SQLite

  • Docker

docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/GiulioRossetti/SuperviseMe.git
cd SuperviseMe

docs.title: 3. Local Python Setup (without Docker)
docs.text:
Create and activate a virtual environment, then install dependencies:

python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt

Prepare environment variables:

cp .env.example .env

At minimum, update these in .env before first run:

  • SECRET_KEY
  • ADMIN_BOOTSTRAP_PASSWORD

docs.text:
You can seed demo data (optional):

python scripts/seed_database.py

docs.title: Existing installation (already has a DB)
docs.text:
If you are upgrading an existing instance, run migration scripts before starting:

python scripts/migrate_database.py
python scripts/migrate_telegram.py
python scripts/migrate_researcher.py

Optional schema check:

python scripts/check_schema_alignment.py

docs.text:
python superviseme.py

Open:

  • http://127.0.0.1:8080

cp .env.example .env
docker-compose up -d

docs.title: Social Login Setup
docs.text: SuperviseMe supports OAuth2 login with Google and ORCID. This allows users to sign in using their existing accounts from these providers.

docs.title: Google Login Setup
docs.text:
To enable Google login, you need to create a project in the Google Cloud Console and obtain OAuth credentials.

  1. Create a Project:

    • Go to the Google Cloud Console.
    • Create a new project or select an existing one.

  2. Configure OAuth Consent Screen:

    • Navigate to APIs & Services > OAuth consent screen.
    • Choose External user type (unless you are in a Google Workspace organization).
    • Fill in the required fields (App name, User support email, Developer contact information).
    • Add scopes: openid, email, profile.
    • Save and continue.

  3. Create Credentials:

    • Navigate to APIs & Services > Credentials.
    • Click Create Credentials > OAuth client ID.
    • Application type: Web application.
    • Name: SuperviseMe (or your preferred name).
    • Authorized JavaScript origins: Add your application's base URL (e.g., https://your-domain.com).
    • Authorized redirect URIs: Add the callback URL: https://your-domain.com/login/google/callback.
      • Note: For local development, use http://localhost:8080/login/google/callback.
    • Click Create.

  4. Configure Environment Variables:

    • Copy the Client ID and Client Secret.
    • Add them to your .env file: 
      GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret

docs.title: ORCID Login Setup
docs.text:
To enable ORCID login, you need to register a public API client with ORCID.

  1. Register for an ORCID Account:

    • If you don't have one, register at ORCID.

  2. Register a Public API Client:

    • Go to Developer Tools.
    • Under Public API, click Register a Public API client.
    • Fill in the details:
      • Name: SuperviseMe
      • Website URL: Your application's URL (e.g., https://your-domain.com).
      • Description: Thesis supervision platform.
      • Redirect URIs: Add the callback URL: https://your-domain.com/login/orcid/callback.
        • Note: For local development, use http://localhost:8080/login/orcid/callback.
    • Save the configuration.

  3. Configure Environment Variables:

    • Copy the Client ID and Client Secret.
    • Add them to your .env file: 
      ORCID_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
ORCID_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret

docs.title: Testing Social Login
docs.text:
1. Restart your application to load the new environment variables.
  2. Go to the login page (/login).
  3. You should see "Sign in with Google" and "Sign in with ORCID" buttons (if configured).
  4. Click on a button to initiate the OAuth flow.
  5. After successful authentication, a new user account will be created (pending admin approval) or you will be logged in if the account already exists.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• HTTPS Requirement: OAuth providers generally require HTTPS for redirect URIs (except for localhost). Ensure your production deployment uses HTTPS.
  • User Approval: New accounts created via social login are disabled by default. An administrator must approve them in the Admin Dashboard.

docs.title: Telegram Notifications Setup Guide
docs.text: SuperviseMe supports Telegram notifications to keep users informed about thesis activities in real-time.

docs.title: Step 1: Create a Telegram Bot
docs.text:
1. Open Telegram and start a chat with @BotFather
  2. Send /newbot command
  3. Follow the instructions to choose a name and username for your bot
  4. Save the Bot Token (format: 123456789:ABCdefGHIjklMNOpqrSTUvwxyz)
  5. Note the Bot Username (without @)

docs.title: Step 2: Configure Bot in SuperviseMe
docs.text:
1. Log in as an administrator
  2. Navigate to Admin > Annotation & Notification Settings
  3. Scroll down to the Telegram Bot Configuration section
  4. Enter your Bot Token and Bot Username
  5. Select which notification types should be available via Telegram
  6. Click Test Bot Connection to verify the configuration
  7. Click Save Telegram Configuration

docs.title: Step 3: Environment Configuration (Optional)
docs.text:
Add these variables to your .env file:

# Telegram Bot Configuration
TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN=your_bot_token_here
TELEGRAM_BOT_USERNAME=your_bot_username_here
BASE_URL=https://your-superviseme-domain.com

docs.title: Step 1: Get Your Telegram User ID
docs.text:
1. Start a chat with your SuperviseMe bot on Telegram
  2. Send any message (e.g., "Hello")
  3. The bot will reply with your Telegram User ID (a number like 123456789)

docs.title: Step 2: Configure Notifications in Profile
docs.text:
1. Log in to SuperviseMe
  2. Go to your Profile page
  3. Scroll down to the Telegram Notifications section
  4. Enter your Telegram User ID from Step 1
  5. Click Verify to test the connection
  6. Enable Telegram Notifications
  7. Select which notification types you want to receive
  8. Click Send Test Message to verify everything works
  9. Click Save Settings

docs.title: Notification Types
docs.text: Type Icon Description Available To New Thesis Update 📝 When a student posts a new thesis update Supervisors New Supervisor Feedback 💬 When a supervisor provides feedback on your thesis Students Task Assignment ✅ When a new task is assigned to you Students, Supervisors Task Completion 🎯 When a task assigned by you is completed Students, Supervisors Thesis Status Change 📊 When your thesis status is updated Students Deadline Reminder ⏰ Reminders for upcoming deadlines Students, Supervisors Weekly Summary 📈 Weekly summary of thesis activities Supervisors

docs.title: Frequency and Granularity
docs.text:
• Immediate: Notifications are sent instantly when events occur
  • Batched: Multiple notifications can be grouped together (future feature)
  • Scheduled: Weekly summaries are sent at configured times
  • Priority-based: High-priority notifications (deadlines) bypass user settings

docs.title: "Bot not configured" error
docs.text:
• Cause: Admin hasn't set up the Telegram bot
  • Solution: Contact your administrator to configure the bot in admin settings

docs.title: "Chat not found" error
docs.text:
• Cause: You haven't started a conversation with the bot
  • Solution: Message the bot on Telegram first, then retry verification

docs.title: "Telegram notifications not enabled for user"
docs.text:
• Cause: You haven't enabled notifications in your profile
  • Solution: Enable Telegram notifications in your profile settings

docs.title: Test message not received
docs.text:
• Cause: Various issues (wrong User ID, bot token, network issues)
  • Solutions:
  • Verify your Telegram User ID is correct
  • Ensure you've started a chat with the bot
  • Check if bot is still active (contact admin)
  • Try disabling and re-enabling notifications

docs.title: Debug Information
docs.text: Administrators can check: - Bot connection status in admin settings - System logs for Telegram API errors - User configuration in the database

docs.title: "Chat not found" error
docs.text:
• Cause: You haven't started a conversation with the bot
  • Solution: Message the bot on Telegram first, then retry verification

docs.title: "Telegram notifications not enabled for user"
docs.text:
• Cause: You haven't enabled notifications in your profile
  • Solution: Enable Telegram notifications in your profile settings

docs.title: Test message not received
docs.text:
• Cause: Various issues (wrong User ID, bot token, network issues)
  • Solutions:
  • Verify your Telegram User ID is correct
  • Ensure you've started a chat with the bot
  • Check if bot is still active (contact admin)
  • Try disabling and re-enabling notifications

docs.title: Debug Information
docs.text: Administrators can check: - Bot connection status in admin settings - System logs for Telegram API errors - User configuration in the database

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
1. Bot Token Security: Keep your bot token secure and never expose it in client-side code
  2. User ID Verification: Users must verify their Telegram User ID to prevent impersonation
  3. Rate Limiting: Telegram API has rate limits; the system respects these automatically
  4. Data Privacy: Only notification content is sent to Telegram; no sensitive data is exposed

docs.title: Migration
docs.text:
Run the migration script to add Telegram functionality to existing installations:

python migrate_telegram.py

This will: - Add new database columns - Create the telegram_bot_config table - Set default notification preferences for existing users - Preserve existing data integrity

docs.title: ORCID Integration
docs.text: SuperviseMe provides integration with ORCID to allow researchers and supervisors to easily import and display their professional activities.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Authentication: Log in using your ORCID credentials.
  • Data Synchronization: Fetch your Works, Employment, Education, and Funding information from ORCID.
  • Visualization: View your imported activities in organized tabs on your profile.
  • Export: Export selected activities or your entire list to BibTeX format.

docs.title: 1. Connect your Account
docs.text: To use the ORCID features, you must log in to SuperviseMe using your ORCID account. - On the Login page, click the Login with ORCID button. - If you don't have an account, one will be created for you based on your ORCID profile.

docs.title: 2. Sync Data
docs.text: Once logged in, go to your Profile page. - You will see an "ORCID Publications" section. - Click the Sync from ORCID button. - The system will fetch your public data from ORCID: - Works: Publications, datasets, etc. - Affiliations: Employment and Education history. - Funding: Grants and awards.

docs.title: 3. View Activities
docs.text: Your activities are displayed in tabs: - Works: List of your publications. - Affiliations: Your employment and education history. - Funding: Your funding records.

docs.title: 4. Export to BibTeX
docs.text: You can export your activities to a BibTeX file for use in LaTeX or other reference managers. - Export All: Click "Export All" to download a BibTeX file containing all your synchronized activities. - Export Selected: Check the boxes next to specific items you wish to export, then click "Export Selected".

docs.title: Technical Details
docs.text:
• Scope: The application uses the /read-public scope to access your public ORCID record.
  • Storage: Data is cached locally in the database for quick access and offline viewing. Syncing overwrites the local cache with the latest data from ORCID.
